channel.title: Posts on James Le Nguyen
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on James Le Nguyen

item.title: Technical Writing
item.description: Similar to playing music, if you’re not practicing daily—you forget things. This was especially true as I couldn’t remember the workflow for this blog, which is somewhat complex as it deals with Hugo, Gitbhub, and Git. After taking some time re-learning the tools, I’m finally back into it. Also, I’ve recently took an interest in technical writing—I’m set on using Antora and will have something up and running by next month.

item.title: New Year
item.description: 2021 comes with it the traditional New year’s resolution and some artificial motivation—had focused on learning SQL syntax and more Python in the meantime. Did I mention I think database are cool!

item.title: Motivation loss
item.description: Started a new computer science course but had slowly loss motivation due to the material’s dryness. I’m certain it’s a good course to learn despite the difficulties in staying focus—will have to get back in to in soon. Time is of the essence!

item.title: Setbacks
item.description: While reading some technical blogs this month, I came across an interesting organization that was dedicated to the improvement of programming and problem solving. After learning more about them, I decided to apply but to my disappointment did not get in. Dealing with setbacks can be hard—just need to continue onward. The application processing was a learning experience in itself, until next time!

item.title: Milestone
item.description: I feel a great milestone has been reached as I’ve completed a python online course! It was both challenging and rewarding at the same time. I know there’s much more ahead of me but wanted to celebrate this achievement with a quick post. And onwards we go into the world of problem solving!

item.title: Learning curve
item.description: Throughout the years, I’ve read blog post and articles about programming and having now personally experiencing it–there is definitely a learning curve but like with anything new you learn–it will be hard at first; move forward and you will be rewarded with new insight and knowledge. And more importantly if you have any self-doubt, find people who can support your learning endevors.(this applies to any subject)

item.title: Python is fun
item.description: In my younger days when I was playing around with the windows command prompt, I remember seeing python in the OS directory but never thought twice what it was or why it was installed—I just figured it was something that made Windows XP work. It’s not until now that I noticed everything connecting and the relation to things that I hadn’t notice before which feels both interesting and somewhat regreftul. Also, did I mention programming is hard.

item.title: A Hero's Journey
item.description: I’ll start this post with a generic but hopfully motivational quote: “Life is full of missed opportunities, especially if you don’t try, you’ll never know what those possibilities could be."—unknown I’ve been working full-time since the completion of my bachelor’s back in 2012 and its funny to think that the only thing I wanted then, was to work. Now, having worked for all these years—school wasn’t so bad (minus the lack of $).
